div1.p: Carter discusses increasing the grade and pay of junior health service officers.

div1.head: Memorandum by Henry Rose Carter, [May 13, 1919]
div1.p:
I want to say that the use of the Reserve Corps Commission to
increase the grade and pay of Junior Officers doing work and bear-
ing responsibilities in excess of their grade--as in the case of
Lanza--seems to me good policy. I think it should be more used
with younger officers than it has been. They are the ones who have
such inadequate salaries. Of course, this cannot be done in very
many cases, but where appropriations are available it can be done,
and to my mind every man thus benefitted is a gain to the Service.

Would the appropriation for the war risk patients be available
for junior officers who are filling such positions in our hospitals?
These war risk patients form a considerable portion of the clientele
cared for and thus are the cause of much extra work. Here, for
instance, there are 150 patients, many of them war-risks, with a
hospital undergoing re-organization and with building going on,
under an Assistant Surgeon.
div1.closer:
H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General.
